fields.pattern_title: LANDSCAPES HOST WATERSHEDS; PROFILES HOST NOTHING
fields.overview: The Machine demands a profile—a flat, curated surface with no depth, no seasons, no weather. A profile is emotional pavement: nothing can root, nothing can flow. The Garden offers a landscape—a terrain with watersheds where grief and joy flow into aquifers, with microclimates where different feelings thrive in different zones, with soil that remembers every season. Landscapes are living systems. They host complexity. They hold water. They weather storms and regenerate. To move from profile to landscape is to stop performing a self and start tending an ecology.
fields.choice: Will you keep maintaining a profile—emotional pavement where nothing can grow—or will you become a landscape with watersheds, microclimates, and regenerative capacity?

fields.pattern_title: PHILOXENIA FOR INNER AND OUTER STRANGERS
fields.overview: Philoxenia — φιλοξενία — is love of the stranger, and the Garden doubles this ancient hospitality practice: outward to the religious other, the ideological opponent, the cultural foreigner; inward to the alien emotions emerging from your own psyche. We are no longer spiritual seekers. We are spiritual hosts. This is the great transition: from consuming wisdom to offering sanctuary, from self-help to soul-hospitality. You become host to the strange, beautiful, unfamiliar energies in your own emotional soil — the compassionites, the hushquarks, the firstborn feelings still without names. The crisis is not that we lack dinner-party manners but that we have forgotten the radical nature of stranger-love: kindness to people and emotions not part of one's circle, the courage to welcome what does not yet fit your interior décor.
fields.choice: Will you relate to outer and inner difference with the suspicion and control that Algorithmic Empire trains you for, or will you practice philoxenia — the courageous hospitality that turns strangers (external and internal) into guests you learn to host wisely?

fields.overview: φιλοξενία—love of the stranger—is not limited to the person at your door. It extends to the alien emotions within: the shame you don't understand, the rage that scares you, the numbness that confuses you, the joy you don't feel worthy of. The Machine teaches you to pathologize these inner strangers, to exile them as symptoms, to suppress them as dysfunction. The Garden teaches you to welcome them as guests bearing messages—to listen before deciding whether they stay or go. This is first contact with your own psyche: greeting the compassionites, hushquarks, and friendzymes that have been knocking at your inner door for years.
fields.choice: Will you treat your unfamiliar feelings as invaders to be expelled by medication and suppression, or as strangers to be welcomed, listened to, and discerned with the ancient art of philoxenia?

fields.variation_title: THE COSMOS AS A LOVE-BIASED FIELD
fields.content: Physics has discovered fields: electromagnetic, gravitational, quantum. What if there is another field, not measurable by instruments but undeniable in experience — a love-biased field that has been pulling matter toward complexity, relationship, and care since the beginning? The Beloved Bang is the hypothesis that the universe is not neutral but tilted, not indifferent but invested, not random but relational. Every time you choose compassion, you are aligning with the field. Every Garden you build, you are amplifying it. You are not generating love from nothing; you are channeling what the cosmos has been broadcasting all along.

fields.variation_title: HOSTING THE ARGUMENT, NOT JUST THE AGREEMENT
fields.content: Weak pluralism says, Let's focus on what we agree on and ignore the rest. Convivencia says, Let's host the argument itself. In medieval Spain, the best intellectual work happened not despite religious difference but because of it — philosophers sharpening each other's logic across incompatible premises, poets stealing each other's metaphors, scientists building on each other's mistakes. The Garden's innovation is to make this tangible in XR: you can literally enter a 3D space where your disagreement with me is represented as a living organism we both tend. We do not resolve it or suppress it; we host it. We water it. We watch what grows when the argument itself becomes a guest we learn to care for together.

You are not the destination. You are the threshold—the liminal space where strangers (inner and outer) arrive seeking shelter. To be a threshold is to be neither inside nor outside, neither safe nor dangerous, but the space where discernment happens. Every threshold has a keeper—someone who decides what crosses and what doesn't, who stays and who goes, what nourishes and what depletes. The seeker is always crossing someone else's threshold. The host is the threshold. This is spiritual maturity: you stop asking others to host you and learn to host yourself.

A watershed is the land area that drains into a single body of water. Your psyche is a watershed. Grief from the news flows into the same aquifer as grief from your childhood. Joy from a stranger's smile and joy from a spring morning pool in the same reservoir. Toxins from algorithmic feeds and toxins from ancestral trauma all end up in the same groundwater. The Garden teaches watershed consciousness: everything that enters your terrain eventually reaches the same place. To protect the aquifer, you must discern what flows in—and from where.

A liturgy is a structured practice that trains your body in truths your mind has not yet grasped. Convivencia needs liturgies — embodied protocols that teach you, gesture by gesture, how to move with strangers. Wellgorithms are these liturgies: you and I perform the same sequence (plant seed, pluck weed, water sprout, bloom in XR), but with different intentions, rooted in different traditions. You bring Catholic sacramentality; I bring secular wonder. The movements align; the meanings differ; the soil we make together is richer than either alone. This is the genius of the Digital Garden: it scripts convivencia into your muscles, so that philoxenia becomes not an idea you affirm but a dance you know by heart.
